Premium.Tensions such as trade tariffs and Brexit seen as biggest risks, survey findsAlmost half of UK businesses expect there will be an economic recession this year, while one in three believes the contraction could be as much as 4 per cent, according to a survey of senior directors.The research, based on 250 senior executives at medium-large sized businesses across the UK, also revealed that well over a third (37 per cent) also expect to see a global recession or international global crisis in 2020.The survey by trade finance provider Stenn found that almost two-thirds of firms ranked increased geopolitical tensions, such as trade tariffs, Brexit&nbspor regional instability, as the number one risk to businesses in 2020.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIncreased environmental concerns and climate change came in as the second largest risk (50 per cent), while changing consumer behaviour, such as shopping online rather than in store, took third place (48 per title: russia libya putin erdogan haftar turkey middle east france italy
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Europe scrambles as Russia flexes diplomatic musclesHastily arranged peace talks brokered by Russia and Turkey have brought leaders of Libya’s two warring factions to Moscow for a surprise meeting that could bring peace to the north African nation while cutting out European powers.&nbspVladimir Putin, the Russian president,&nbspand&nbspRecep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish&nbsppresident,&nbsphammered out a truce leading to peace talks late last week.On Monday, just days after insisting he would not negotiate with “terrorists” in Tripoli, Libya’s renegade commander Khalifa Haftar and his adversary Fayez al-Sarraj​, prime minister of the UN-brokered Government of National Accord, arrived in the Russian capital for peace talks.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesBy day’s end it remained unclear if any lasting deal would be be struck, with reports that Mr Haftar’s delegation had left meetings without signing&nbspa final statement expressing support for a truce. Mr Sarraj’s delegation also insisted in statements to media that it had refused to sit down with Mr Haftar.It was nonetheless a stunning and unexpected turn in the Libya conflict, and another instance of Mr Putin using the levers of diplomacy to put his imprint on the geopolitics of the Middle East and north Africa. France, Italy, Germany and other European and Arab powers scrambled to catch up.“Until a few weeks ago the Europeans were happy&nbsptaking their sweet time,” said Jalel Harchaoui, a north Africa specialist at the Clingendael Institute, a Dutch think tank. “Now what we’re seeing is not about concrete peace as about a change of venue and the emergence of Moscow as the superpower that all the actors are happy to speak with.”Created with Sketch.Protests against Turkey sending forces to Libya Show all 12Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A woman brandishing a rifle takes part in a demonstration held by Libyans and Syrians in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi to protest against Turkey's prospective military interventionTurkish members of parliament vote to send Turkish troops to Libya. They passed a bill approving a military deployment to Libya aimed at shoring up the UN-backed government in Tripoli, at a time of intensifying international tensions over the conflict. The beleaguered Tripoli government has been under sustained attack since April by military strongman General Khalifa Haftar, who is backed by Turkey's regional rivals - Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the United Arab EmiratesA woman brandishing a rifle takes part in a demonstration held by Libyans and Syrians in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi to protest against Turkey's prospective military interventionTurkish members of parliament vote to send Turkish troops to Libya. They passed a bill approving a military deployment to Libya aimed at shoring up the UN-backed government in Tripoli, at a time of intensifying international tensions over the conflict. The beleaguered Tripoli government has been under sustained attack since April by military strongman General Khalifa Haftar, who is backed by Turkey's regional rivals - Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the United Arab EmiratesMr Haftar’s Libyan National Army and forces loyal to Mr Sarraj’s government have been at war over the capital, Tripoli, since April, in a conflict that has cost hundreds of lives and drawn in the interference of regional powers.&nbspMr Haftar, a former armed forces officer, launched the war promising a quick victory to his backers in Cairo and the Gulf. Western Libyan forces rallied and prevented him from entering the capital.&nbspTurkey, a strong backer of Mr Sarraj’s government, in recent weeks began to deploy troops, allied Syrian fighters, and sophisticated military hardware to Libya to counter Mr Haftar’s forces, which are backed by the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Saudi Arabia.&nbspTurkey’s overt intervention and its escalating influence in Libya has prompted alarm in France and among other backers of Mr Haftar, including eastern Mediterranean countries worried about Ankara’s attempts to lay claim to offshore gas reserves.&nbspOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailNews of the Russian and Turkish brokered talks set off a flurry of high-level diplomacy. Abdel ​Fattah ​el-Sisi, Egypt’s president and Mr Haftar’s primary backer and mentor, conferred with Angela Merkel, the&nbspGerman chancellor, over Libya.&nbspGermany now says it plans to hold long-planned Libya peace talks in Berlin on 19 January.&nbspItaly, Libya’s former colonial overlord, also appeared eager to re-engage in the Libya matter.Despite praise for the deal in the Turkish press, experts say the prospects for a lasting peace are dim. Though Mr Sarraj​ and Mr Haftar&nbspare in Moscow there is no plan for the two men to meet.&nbspMr Sarraj commands a measure of loyalty from the powerful armed factions that are pillars of the Government of National Accord but has little control over them. Mr Haftar could be using the peace talks to consolidate gains and buy time to rearm after his recent taking of the central Libyan city of Sirte. In the days since the ceasefire went into effect both sides have accused the other of violating its terms.&nbspTurkey sends troops and electronic warfare tools to Libya Turkey approves deployment of troops to Libya in high-stakes battleTrump will come last in the Mediterranean gas race over LibyaBy wading into Libya, Erdogan risks a major Mediterranean conflictUS military drone ‘shot down by Russian forces in Libya’Mr Haftar may have ultimately acceded to the talks under pressure from his Egyptian and Emirati backers, who were lobbied by Mr Putin. “He’s cornered,” said Mr Harchaoui. “He’s already been given far more time and resources than he initially asked for. He cannot keep asking for more time. The Emiratis know they have time to fine tune the picture later on.”Mr Putin also has a history of making flashy diplomatic announcements in order to increase Russia’s diplomatic leverage and standing, only to walk away and let others deal with the fallout when agreements flounder and the shooting resumes.&nbsp“It’s premature to talk about peace,” said Anas el-Gomati, a founder of the Sadeq&nbspInstitute, a think tank focused on Libya. “The ceasefire will be temporary. It’s not designed to be operational. It’s designed for consumption. Russia is not interested in Libya. It’s interested in using Libya to pressure Europe and Turkey.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: labour leadership clive lewis racism
story: Clive Lewis is well short of the  nominations he needs from MPs and MEPs to stay in the race beyond Monday.He said “structural racism is a reality of our society” and said the Parliamentary Labour party “isn’t immune from the same forces that affect everyone within our society”.He was speaking at the launch of his leadership campaign in Brixton, South London.Mr Lewis, the shadow economics minister, used the event to call for a referendum on the future of the Royal Family.The shadow treasury minister said: We are a democracy. I’d rather see us as citizens than subjects in the st Century.Mr Lewis called for the Royal Family referendum as part of a package of sweeping constitutional reforms, including replacing the current first past the post electoral system with proportional representation.The shadow minister also said that Labour must modernise or die.Mr Lewis said: We cant have more of the same. The Labour Party needs to modernise or it will die.Im fed up with the top-down style of politics, where real debate and discussion in our party is stled because of sectarianism and tribalism.We cant grow as a partywere afraid of having dficult discussions.Im standing because I see a party in crisis and democracy in crisis, and unless we start addressing some fundamental issues, a few tweaks of policy here, or a slight change of leader there, arent going to bring the real change that this country urgently needs.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: samira ahmed wins bbc equal pay
story: The Newswatch host was told she should have got the same as Jeremy Vine, who earned £, an episode for Points Of View.Samira, , insisted their roles were comparable — but the BBC argued it was not similar work.Yesterday, an employment tribunal ruled in favour of Samira, who earned just £ an episode, saying: “The dference in pay in this case is striking.”It said Jeremy, , just had to read from a script, adding: “If it told him to roll his eyes he did. It did not require any particular skill or experience to doBut the tribunal did not say whether Samira should get the £, she said she was owed.The ruling, following a hearing in November in London, will have major implications for BBC pay.Ms Ahmed said: “I’m now looking forward to reporting on stories and not being one.”Carrie Gracie, who quit as BBC China editor two years ago over pay, told her: “I could not be more proud of you.I hope your victory gives courage to women to stand up for the value of their work.”But the BBC insisted: “We have always believed that the pay of Samira and Jeremy Vine was not determined by their gender.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says harry meghan bankrolled
story: Their plan for global domination as Instagram’s “progressive” royal power couple looks fatally flawed.First it relies on them still being bankrolled by an increasingly enraged public — as they magnanimously “work to become financially independent” despite already being worth sums most of us cannot imagine.Second, because when they finally deem their wealth vast enough to cut that umbilical cord, their livelihood will still centre around their image as senior royals . . . a role they have quit.The idea of them busily enriching themselves by flogging their part-time royalty to advertisers will disgust taxpayers — both on principle and because this ­entitled pair will never refund a penny back into Treasury coffers.The UK public will justiably demand they be cut off at the ankles, stripped of the titles on which they trade.What then for plain Meghan and Harry Wales, the narcissist formerly known as Prince Who will listen then to their vapid sermons  They might fancy themselves as the new Clintons or Obamas — but they have not earned their  or status.They were born into it, or married into it, but gave it up when it all looked too dull, too hard and not enough fun.Diehard fans will stick by them. They will doubtless make big money. But the firestorm of criticism they have ignited here will become an inferno.It is a disastrous mess and may get worse. The couple’s assumption about the public continuing to fund round-the-clock security in Canada looks ­premature — and must be reviewed.Harry is worth £million, Meghan another £million. How much richer must they be before they pay that bill WHY is the Government still so coy about celebrating the moment of Brexit Leaving the EU at pm on January  will be a huge milestone in our modern history, the end of our -year membership and the starting gun for negotiating a lucrative new era of trade.The Sun wants Big Ben to bong. We want bunting, fireworks and, yes, commemorative Royal Mail stamps.We understand the feelings of Remainers. But there were plenty of them among the million who voted last month to “get Brexit done”.The big day is less than three weeks away following its final passage through the Commons on Thursday.How typical of Labour, given one last chance to vote for the deal securing our exit, to remain childishly opposed to it.Defeated in the referendum, crushed at the election. title: boris should not bend opinion
story: Previously, in weeks where Brexit legislation was before the Commons, discussion was dominated by whether or not the Government had the numbers to win the vote and how it should respondit did not.This time there was barely a mention of Brexit despite the votes on it this week. .Pretty much all Boris Johnson had to say on the matter was to urge ministers to, “banish Brexit”, from their lexicons after January , when the UK leaves the EU.Boris wants ministers to stop talking about Brexit once the UK has left as he doesn’t want the trade negotiations with the EU to dominate British politics in the way that leaving has since the referendum. He wants to show voters that the country has moved on and the Government is once more focusing on the domestic issues voters care about.But however much he tries, it will be hard to make these talks boring. They are important and there is already DRAMA BREWING.Boris saw the new Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in Downing Street this week. The pair got on well in their hour-long meeting. They both want these talks to be less acrimonious than the orce negotiations both want a more cordial tone.The pair reminisced about the school they had both attended in Brussels. Unlike Eton, it didn’t have playing fields, and until Johnson arrived the only game in the playground was marbles. He introduced some more rough and tumble.No were pleased that von der Leyen, rather than the more confrontational Michel Barnier, took the lead. As one No source points out, the EU loathed the lack of clarity and authority under Theresa May: She wasn’t clear what she wanted and it wasn’t certain that she could deliver what she wanted.With Boris and his new majority it is very dferent. He was able to point von der Leyen to the Tory manesto’s commitments on the future trade deal and say this was his mandate and that he was determined to deliver it.Yet despite the pair’s attempt to maintain a friendly tone, there are already tensions. Boris is irritated that the EU keeps saying it is nigh-on impossible to negotiate a full trade deal by December , despite having signed up to a political declaration that commits it to trying to do just that.The DANGER is that the EU thinks that under time pressure Boris will bend, that he will either extend the transition period — something he has repeatedly promised not to do — or drop his commitment to breaking away from EU rules and regulations.Boris is determined not to do either of these things. He doesn’t want to extend and believes in the value of the UK having the right to do things dferently.Both sides have frequently misunderstood each other in this process. Both sides must now realise that the other means what it says. Unless they do, there is going to be an almighty bust-up and no trade deal at the end of all this.THERE will be a National Security Council meeting later this month to decide whether or not to allow the Chinese company Huawei to be involved in the construction of the UK’s G network.This is an issue of fierce debate in Whitehall. Under Theresa May, it led to the then Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson’s sacking from government.Hawkish figures inside government fear No is leaning towards allowing Huawei’s involvement. One complains that Downing Street’s timetable for the technology’s roll-out is, “not realistic”, but that this time pressure means it will need Huawei involved. However, I understand that the Americans are pushing very hard for the UK to bar Huawei.One senior US government national security figure has been in London this week to lobby directly on this point.Before he makes a decision on Huawei, Boris Johnson should consider the damage it could do to Britain’s most important security relationship – the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing agreement with Australia, Canada, the US and New Zealand.Eventhe UK thinks it can manage Huawei’s involvement,our allies do not then we shouldn’t proceed. It is simply not worth the risk of undermining such a vital alliance.Don’t expect his approach to change. His holidays will be far more glam than Cameron and May’s were.THE most common reason British governments fail is that the Prime Minister and the Chancellor fall out.If No and the Treasury – the most powerful department in government – aren’t on the same page, nothing gets done.Boris Johnson and Sajid Javid are determined to avoid this fate. In the run-up to the Budget on March , there will be a huge effort to make sure that the Treasury and No work together.One Johnson ally tells me the two men will have a Budget-focused meeting at the start of each week to make sure they are in agreement on the key issues.Then their teams will meet again mid-week to assess progress. Javid, whose job is safe in the coming reshuffle, is determined to show that the Treasury is capable of delivering on Boris Johnson’s agenda of levelling up across the country.Those close to him are confident that they can put meat on the bones of No’s plan.AT Cabinet this week it was impressed on ministers that one of the most important events this year is COP, the climate change conference the UK is hosting in Glasgow in November.The UK Government wants to use the event to show how Britain can lead on clean growth post-Brexit.I understand there will be a steady drum beat of announcements on this front throughout the year: The Tories want to show they are helping create new green-collar jobs.They also hope that by holding the event in Scotland, they can emphasise the benefits of the Union.THE Labour leadership contest has yet to catch fire.The Tories are not particularly concerned about any of the candidates.Though there is some hesitation about how they would handle PMQs with Jess Phillips, who likes to make very personal attacks on Boris Johnson.But the most interesting candidate in the race is Lisa Nandy.She seems to have the clearest understanding of why Labour lost.Her bid is starting to have faint echoes of David Cameron’s successful tilt at the Tory leadership in .GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. Harry and Meghan expect to still have a handle on royal duty but also to lead a private le.What they mean by living financially independent, I don’t know. They aren’t financially independent now — they get £.- million from the Prince Of Wales and about five per cent from the Sovereign Grant.Harry is reasonably wealthy but not necessarily in cash flow. The sums he inherited from his mother and great grandmother have been invested.Meghan has some means but to live the sort of lestyle they are used to takes a lot of money.It is conceivable Charles could cut the money he gives to Harry —he gives him any at all. Being a dad, he probably will.But there are tax implications — particularlythere are handouts.Security has also to be considered. Harry is a prince of the United Kingdom, his grandmother head of state and father heir.The atmosphere at the meeting will be, up to a point, heated. But people won’t lose their tempers.The Queen is pragmatic. She understands problems people have but Harry will be fully aware of her displeasure. To go off half-cocked as he and Meghan did is unacceptable.The question is how dare they do that. She signed up for this. So what’s changed their minds I’d love to be a fly on the wall of the events in that meeting . . . provided no one has a fly swat!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. She has a son mired in a squalid sex scandal. And she is  years old. Who the hell do Harry and Meghan think they are This feels like an abdication with a taxpayer-funded safety net. The couple plan to “step back as senior members of the Royal Family” but show no inclination to give up the privileges and pay days that come with the job.They say they want to “work to become financially independent”. But between them they are currently worth around £million. Why not pay their own way NOW Are they really suggesting that they turn their backs on this nation while asking it to foot their bills  It looks like it. The British taxpayer will continue to stump up for their phenomenal security bills. Harry’s daddy will cough up for much .So you can’t help wondering how intelligent they really are, this TV soap actress and a man who left Eton with two A-levels— a school where my dog could get four A-levels.Do Harry and Meghan really think they have had a raw deal  Are they that stupid  There is no republican movement in this country.The Queen has reigned far too well for far too long —  years on the throne next month — for anti-monarchy sentiment to develop.The Queen has spent her entire le placing public duty above private happiness.She has been the stable, stoic centre of this nation for so long that she has single-handedly made losing our monarchy unthinkable.Yet when a spokesman for anti-monarchy pressure group Republic demanded Harry and Meghan make a clean break, I found myself nodding in agreement with every withering word.“Theyhave said that they will dip in and out of royal duties as it suits them but won’t stop taking money until they find other sources of income,” said Republic’s Graham Smith.“To suggest they’re not already financially independent is incredibly crass and belies a sense of entitlement and lack of self-awareness common among royals.”This republican is right. If Harry and Meghan want a new le hanging out with the Clooneys and striking deals with Apple, they should fund it themselves.As they say in North America, do it on your own dime. Give up the HRH titles. Stop leeching off your royal status.They will be a footnote in the story of our Royal Family, Meghan the Wallis Simpson of the st Century, Harry another Duke of Windsor who believed exile with his American orcee would make him happy.The Royal Family is not all about them.The Queen will be an impossible act to follow. But the photograph of Queen Elizabeth smiling proudly with the next three generations of future kings — Princes Charles, William and George — suggests our Royal Family will last for at least  years after Netflix has cancelled The Crown, evenone day Meghan gets to play herself.The succession is assured. Decent men will wear the crown. And Kate is great. But let history record that no royal couple was ever as adored as Harry and Meghan.It is astonishing — and unbelievably sad, perhaps even tragic — that millions of us will be happy to see the back of them.Astrological patterns repeat in families through generations, just as it is doing with Meghan and Harry.Edward VIII, who wed American orcee Wallis Simpson, put love before duty, and planted a karmic seed that is at the root of what is unfolding now. It can be likened to a virus that has been lurking in the Royal household and is now being re-activated by Harry and Meghan.So what comes next  Uranus, the planet of shock-waves, moves to confront the Sun in Aquarius on January  and forms a clash with the New Moon on the th.There is likely to be a stinging backlash as all the remaining senior family members have their roles shaken up.Meghan will create a power couple that flourishes by spring with a number of initiatives. By December , another baby announcement is likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour contender clive lewis sparks outcry after claiming brexit vote had racism at its core
story: The Norwich South MP said non-white Britons woke up with a “sense of dread” the day after the referendum, which will see Britain finally leave on January .Having previously suggested racism was a reason some Labour MPs were not backing him, the arch-Remainer now also claimed it was integral to Brexit.He said: “I think part of the Brexit campaign, and part of the undertone of Brexit, from some politicians, Nigel Farage and others, had racism at its core and its heart.“They used it as a mechanism to ide our communities, to ide our country.“How many people of colour, how many people of colour, on the day after the referendum with a sense of dread because of what had happened “Ultimately our country had chosen to listen to Boris Johnson, someone who has a track record of racist commentary, of giving credence to racism.”Despite his bizarre claims, the leadership hopeful admitted some of his own family voted to leave the EU.He said: Now that doesn’t mean that every single person that voted for Brexit is a racist, some of my family voted for Brexit but I think there were drivers within that campaign that certainly were very unsavoury and what I would call racist.”The radical leftie also called for the Royal Family and private schools to be abolished.His comments sparked fury among Brexiteers, with Sir Iain Duncan Smith labelling them “breathtaking absurdity”.He said: “He’s saying this about . million people.“The present Labour party does not understand why people have turned away from them.“The Labour party think they won the election but were finally let down by the British people at the end.”Passionate Brexiteer Steve Baker also blasted the leadership contenders claims.He said: “Clive’s hysterics are not just wrong, they obviously didn’t work with the British public, who are far too sensible for this rubbish.“It’s time to pull together, not sow more ision.”

title: michael fabricant letter to queen
story: In his letter to Her Majesty, Michael Fabricant says Buckingham Palace’s dilemma over what to do with Prince Harry “could be turned into a huge triumphthey accept his proposal.And the MP says that far from being “a cause for sorrow,” the decision by Harry and Meghan to quit the Firm and relocate to Canada could instead be “a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country at large”.He says the move would also bolster the monarchy’s reputation internationally and give the UK “an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union”.He points to a poll that found six in ten Canadians were in favour of Prince Harry becoming Governor General of Canada.Mr Fabricant says Prince Harry would be “well-suited to this role” due to his “valiant service in the Army” and charity work.The Governor is formally appointed by the Queen on the advice of the Canadian PM to carry out her constitutional and ceremonial duties in the country.The current incumbent is Julie Payette, an astronaut from Quebec, who has served since .Governors usually serve for five years but there is no constitutional timeframe.Mr Fabricant says that while she has done a “sterling job,” nobody has the “same kind of box office appeal that Harry does”.In his letter he writes: “As Your Majesty will no doubt be aware, the decision by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to step back from their royal duties to spend more time in North America has caused quite a stir among your loyal subjects.“While many disapprove of this, may I make the case that this can in fact be a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country at large  A challenge could be turned to a huge triumph.”He adds: “While their methods and approach to royal duties may not always fall in line with tradition, there is no doubting that Harry and Meghan are seen by many of the younger generation as symbols of a new, modern, vibrant monarchy.”“Installing Harry as Governor General would not only bolster support for the Monarchy internationally, but also provide Canada, and by extension the United Kingdom, an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union.“There is also little doubt that Harry would be well-suited to this role.His valiant service in the Army, as well as his numerous charity works, give him more than enough experience to serve as Your Majestys representative to Canada.”As Your Majesty will no doubt be aware, the decision by the Duke and Duchess of Sussex to step back from their royal duties to spend more time in North America has caused quite a stir among your loyal subjects.While many disapprove of this, may I make the case that this can in fact be a wonderful opportunity for both the Royal Family and our country at large  A challenge could be turned to a huge triumph.The departure of the Sussexes from these shores need not be a cause for sorrow. A recent Postmedia poll in Canada found that over % there were in favour of Prince Harry becoming the Governor General of Canada.The poll also showed that it was younger Canadians who would be most in favour of such a move, and that even in the generally French republican province of Quebec, almost half would also support this.The current Governor General, Julie Payette, who has been in post since , has done a sterling job. However, neither she, nor anyone  who has previously held this position, possess the same kind of box office appeal that Harry does.While their methods and approach to royal duties may not always fall in line with tradition, there is no doubting that Harry and Meghan are seen by many of the younger generation as symbols of a new, modern, vibrant monarchy.Installing Harry as Governor General would not only bolster support for the Monarchy internationally, but also provide Canada, and by extension the United Kingdom, an enormous boost in soft power at an important juncture for our country as we depart the European Union.Procedurally, there would be few barriers to making this a reality. The Governor General is appointed to the role on the advice of Canadian Prime Minister, and while the convention is for the Governor General to serve for around five years, there are no specic constitutional requirements for this.Thus,this is something Harry himself wished to do, a call from Her Majesty to Justin Trudeau would go a long way in pushing this along.I have the honour to remain, Madam, Your Majesty’s most humble and obedient servant.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: keir starmer posh remainer leader
story: It was this “Posh Trot” Remainer who drove a bulldozer through Labour’s so-called Red Wall and cleared the path for Boris Johnson’s invasion of its northern heartlands.It was Starmer’s campaign for a chaotic second referendum that persuaded millions of working-class supporters to vote Tory for the first time and condemn Labour to the political wilderness.Not surprisingly, Starmer’s critics now wonder why this proven loser is in pole position to run their party.Some point the finger at Gordon Brown quietly rallying supporters to the cause.The ex-PM and his protegé have been close since Starmer’s controversial reign as Director of Public Prosecutions from  to .Starmer, despite his reputation for defending human rights, is not above sly ploys.There is nothing wrong with being wealthy — except among the Momentum voters he needs to seize Labour’s crown. Perhaps this explains why his Wikipedia entry has just been doctored to delete his status as a “millionaire”. Not me, guv, protests Starmer.He is also weirdly reluctant to declare where he stands on the political spectrum. Is he a Corbynite or a Blairite or a bit of both  “I don’t have the names of former leaders tattooed on my head,” snfs the man named at birth after the first leader of the Labour Party.This knight of the realm, who played violin at fee-paying Reigate Grammar School alongside Fatboy Slim, claims a humble background as the son of a toolmaker.“I know what it’s like,” he insists, asraised in a cardboard box.Well, I went to the same school when it was a “bog-standard” state grammar. My father was a journeyman upholsterer. It didn’t give me any special insights.Starmer boasts in his new campaign video about picket-line stints alongside down- trodden Wapping printworkers — against my boss, Rupert Murdoch, a hate figure on the Left.This chameleon politician was dubbed a “Sir” on the recommendation of Gordon Brown, a title he discourteously declines to use because it invites contempt among those with a vote.His citation was for “services to law and criminal justice”, after a five-year term as DPP.At about the same time he was parachuted into Parliament as MP for rock-solid Labour Holborn and St Pancras, in London.It is here that self-respecting Labour voters should pause and reflect.Many believe these political plums were reward for the longest, costliest and perhaps most spiteful criminal persecution in history — ordered by Sir Keir Starmer.His new leadership video slyly refers to this time, apparently to boost his scourge-of-capitalism image among the “comrades” — even though politics should play no part in a DPP’s decision-making. In a travesty of justice, he rammed two dozen innocent journalists through Old Bailey trials on trumped-up conspiracy charges — a medieval catch-all which even the Crown Prosecution Service admitted was “an extremely dficult and rarely visited area of the law”.The prosecuting counsel was given a flea in his ear for “chopping and changing”, the charges against the journalists.The trials ended with acquittals all round, an admission that “no crime may have been committed” and this rebuke from the Lord Chief Justice:“What concerns me is the freedom of the Press and the desire of officials to contain information.“We must ensure the Press is protected — we can’t use criminal sanctions to undermine their position.”The defendants were all journalists on The Sun or the News of the World — then seen by the Left as fair game.The trials followed The Sun’s decision to switch its support from Gordon Brown’s floundering regime to David Cameron’s Tories.Some believe the two were linked — but surely that’s just a conspiracy theory.What is absolutely clear to those who care about the issue is Starmer’s readiness to use his power to curb Press freedom.As citizens of totalitarian regimes rapidly learn to their cost, without a free Press there is no such thing as free speech.IT’S win-win for the Sussexes and losses all round for the House of Windsor.Meghan’s first kiss-and-tell will be a bestseller, with all the gossip on Randy Andy and those secret royal scandals.Harry’s right-on charities will be milked for millions.Once our revered Queen has departed, the monarchy will dwindle to a sideshow on the US celebrity circuit.Charles is too old to compete and William is too dull, despite Kate’s best efforts.Hero Harry will emerge as victor in this grotesque civil war. Meg’s mum Doria has been pictured leaving Oprah’s home.Harry has already worked with Oprah for an Apple TV series on mental health.The couple left the royal family reeling when they revealed they would step down as senior royals and split their time between Northern America and the UK.And the Duke of Sussex has been left to pick up the pieces at the crunch talks today after Meghan, , fled to Canada.It has been reported the Royal Family had not been consulted before the Sussexes released their statement – with the palace saying there were “complicated issues that will take time to work through”.Harry, , was originally said by a royal source to have felt pushed out of the royal family by his big brother, reported The Times.According to repeated reports, Harry felt that William was insufficiently welcoming towards Meghan when they first started dating.Their relationship has apparently not recovered since.But in a joint statement released today, the brothers said: “Despite clear denials, a  story ran in a UK newspaper today speculating about the relationship between The Duke of Sussex and The Duke of Cambridge.“For brothers who care so deeply about the issues surrounding mental health, the use of inflammatory language in this way is offensive and potentially harmful.”Today, the -year-old monarch aims to define what the future roles of Meghan and Harry will be.This includes how the couple will be able to continue supporting charities while not conflicting with any private work they might undertake to become financially independent.Announcing their decision last week, Harry and Meghan said they wanted to “carve out a progressive new role within this institution”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince charles prince harry meghan markle

It does not take into account security for one thing and much of the travel.Also talk of what the Prince of Wales only pays towards both his sons from the profits of the Duchy is simply not true. He has paid out considerable sums from his private investments and money too.These are not small sums. It should not be a surprise that he is upset by all this given the truth about how he has supported his son.”Meghan and Harry announced last week they will work towards being financially independent - but are still retaining certain royal privileges.They will lose £million-a-year from the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant - but will have  per cent of their brand-Sussex costs paid for by Harrys dad through the Duchy of Cornwall.Meghan and Harry will continue to live at Frogmore Cottage on the grounds of Windsor Castle, which saw a £.million taxpayer-funded refurbishment carried out last year.The Grade II listed, four-bedroom home is owned by the Queen - with the pair having to seek permission to use the house while they split their time between the UK and North America.Despite stepping down from the royal family, the couple will still be awarded security at the hands of the taxpayer.As they are deemed internationally protected people by the Home Office, they require constant armed security from the politan Police.Meghan and Harry announced this arrangement would continue - with an estimated £, bill for their six police bodyguards charged to the British taxpayer.The Queen, Harry, Charles and Prince William are currently locked in crisis talks at Sandringham over the royal orce.Her Majesty also aims to sort the Sussexes’ roles, and Meghan, , could join in via conference call.The former actress is currently in Canada with baby Archie after flying back on a budget flight as news of the split broke.The Palace said they would not be commenting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: julian assange mia supporter
story: The Paper Planes star was among dozens of supporters who packed out Westminster Magistrates Court as the Wikileaks founder battles to avoid being sent to the US, where he faces  charges.Wearing a black jacket, grey jumper and glasses, Assange spoke only to confirm his name, his date of birth, and to briefly state he did not understand an element of proceedings, during the -minute hearing.The -year-old saluted his supporters in the public gallery as he was brought into court.Assanges lawyers complained they had not had enough time to discuss the case with him at Belmarsh prison, where he is being held, before the hearing.His lawyer Gareth Peirce said: It is a breach of a defendants rights.Assange raised his right fist as he was led to the cells, after District Judge Vanessa Baraitser adjourned the hearing to give them more time to talk.About  protesters maintained a vigil outside court, chanting Assanges name and calling for him to be freed.Supporters queued for  minutes to get into the building.MIA, real name Mathangi Arulpragasam, was among more than  people allowed inside the packed public gallery.Speaking outside court, she said: I am off to get a medal at Buckingham Palace tomorrowand I think today is just as important.To give somebody an hour to put their case together is not right.Australian Assange is accused of working with former US army intelligence analyst Cha Manning to leak hundreds of thousands of classied documents.Assange was jailed for  weeks in May last year for breaching his bail conditions, after going into hiding in the Ecuadorian embassy in London to avoid extradition to Sweden over sex offence allegations, which he has always denied.Swedish authorities later dropped the rape investigation.He had been in custody since he was dramatically removed from the embassy building in April.The case was adjourned and Assanges full extradition hearing is scheduled for next month.

title: who peter farquhar novelist teacher maids moreton
story: The novelists death wasnt initially treated as suspicious. Heres everything we know.Mr Farquhar was born in Edinburgh and was the son of a GP.Farquhar, who used to be a lay preacher at Stowe Parish Church, was educated at Cambridge University.He taught English for  years at Manchester Grammar School before becoming a department head at posh Stowe School in Buckinghamshire.As well as lecturing, Mr Farquhar published three novels through Amazon, and a character in the  football film Believe was based on him during his time teaching in Manchester.Farquhar’s first book — titled Between Boy and Man — tells of a school chaplain who struggles to ­reconcile his Christian faith with his gay impulses.Mr Farquhar died on October , , and friends and family said that they believed he had died in his sleep after a short illness.The inquest, held in Beaconsfield, Bucks., just a month later, recorded the accidental death verdict after a short hearingOn January , , it was revealed that Farquhar’s cause of death was initially ruled to be the result of accidental alcohol poisoning.Richard Hulett, the now retired coroner for Buckinghamshire, recorded the accidental death verdict after hearing from a pathologist that a post-mortem examination showed that the former teacher died as a result of acute alcohol intoxication.Peter published three books before he died.Ben Fields, , was Peters toyboy lover.Peter could not believe his luck when handsome Ben Field — who, at , was more than four decades his junior — started dating him.As their relationship developed, they even had a church betrothal ceremony, in which they exchanged crucix necklaces.But “psychopath” Field was also seeing FOUR women.He had embarked on a “gaslighting” campaign of drugging, deceiving and defrauding Peter to get him to change his will.

title: debenhams uk store closures latest
story: Read on to find out which branches are set to close, and why.Debenhams is shutting  of its stores this month, as it continues its massive programme of shop closures.At the end of , it was revealed that Debenhams was set to close  of its stores.But  stores have been confirmed to shut in the next three weeks, including Altrincham, Wolverhampton, Ashford and Wimbledon.Heres the full list of closures announced so far:Its believed to be a combination of increasing rents, business rates and a rise in online shopping.Richard Lim of Retail Economics, told the BBC in October  that Debenhams leases and spiralling operating costs are set against a backdrop an accelerating behavioural sht towards online and experiences.This is eroding their profitability and changes in the business need to occur at a pacethey are to survive.Speaking at the time, Debenhams executive chairman Terry Duddy said: Debenhams has a clear strategy and a bright future, but in order for the business to prosper, we need to restructure the groups store portfolio and its balance sheet, which are not appropriate for todays much changed retail environment.Our priority is to save as many stores and as many jobs as we title: uk weather forecast 80mph storm brendan
story: A double “weather bomb” is set to leave a trail of disruption with hurricane-force gales, ft waves, floods and snow.Met Office forecaster Marco Petagna said: “Storm Brendan brings risks of short-term power loss and transport delays, with gusts up to mph locally in the North-West.Thursday sees another system with potential for severe gales similar in strength to Tuesdays gusts, with the West including Scotland most at risk.The torment is a double weather bomb because the Met Office forecasts showed the storm is strengthening as its air pressure plunges by around  millibars in  hours - double the  millibars needed to qualy as a weather bomb.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning for high winds across the west, south-west and north-east of the country between am and midnight on Monday.While the North East of Scotland is expect to be hit from lunch time today to midnight tomorrow.This morning  more than  homes were blacked out after electricity failures near Falmouth and Truro in Cornwall as the winds began bringing trees down across cables.There are also warnings of potential flooding caused by heavy showers of torrential rain.Blustery conditions are already causing trouble in the North East with an Easyjet flight erted from Newcastle to Edinburgh Airport.Film captured on Saturday showed at least two ersions, with one Jet Boeing - having to perform a go-around as the wind hit mph.Easyjets flight from Malaga had to pull up at the last minute as a gust threatened to destabilise its landing.After four attempts it was erted to Edinburgh. A Jet flight was also erted to Manchester.Ireland is already dealing with the consequences of Storm Brendan with at least  homes in County Cork affected by power cuts as of this morning.Yesterday it was a reported that a man had been swept out to sea by large waves on the Blackpool seafront as the country braces for strong winds from Storm Brendan.Concerns were raised late on Saturday by a member of the public after they looked down from the promenade and saw a man on the beach very close to the water.HM Coastguard launched an intensive search but no trace of anyone was found.RAC spokesman Simon Williams told people to take extra care as , RAC call-outs are expected today.He said: Dont get caught by one of winters fiercest storms so far.

title: harry meghan megxit
story: NewsopinionThe one thing Harry and Meghan werent expecting: "One wants to come with"As Royals gather for the Sandringham Summit, our columnist Fleet Street Fox wonders whether Megxit is going to snowballShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMegsie, you wonapost believe it. Granny and Pops have agreed to all our demands. We stay HRH, keep the cops, and theyaposve even signed off on a megabucks deal for banana-flavoured condoms with inspirational messages on them. Thereaposs just one problem. They want to come with us.  The WhatsApp messages that Meghan receives in her Pacic Ocean hideaway following the Sandringham Summit will probably not make the happiest of reading for their recipient. Because what the Duke and Duchess of Sussex donapost seem to have quite figured out is that their Megxit is an awful lot like Brexit. And some of itaposs not possible. Half of them want a massive change because theyaposre unhappy with the way things have been for the past , years. Itaposs all about taking back control, and lots of promises have been made about how great itaposs going to be on the sunlit uplands currently just out of sight, behind that massive constitutional obstacle. The real problem is that, now a vote has been publicly expressed, how much of it can be delivered without smashing the country to smithereens.  Some people think itaposs all about race, others that itaposs to do with sovereignty, and thereaposs a lot of speculation and  claims about a thing that nobody in the country will admit they do not have a clue about. A large chunk of it is definitely to do with the Britainaposs long-held, fascinated disdain for all things American. All itaposs really lacking is a bus. Almost certainly, whatever plans are proposed for the Sussexes to consider, will take longer and involve more compromises than expected. You can make your own money, but the palace needs oversight of your contracts. You can live where you like, but choose a tax jurisdiction and stick with it. And the government reserves the right to tell you to shut up. Perhaps those are prices theyaposll decide itaposs wise to pay, for the sake of freedom. They were wise enough to ensure their son Archie had no title. Leaposs much better without one - just ask Zara Tindall.  The Queen will have seen how Brexit was made more damaging simply by dragging on for years. Megxit,it is to go well, must happen quickly - on paper,not in practice. So thereaposs the Queen in one corner, Philip upstairs in bed, hollering and banging his bedpan on the ceiling. A jetlagged Prince Charles on one side, wishing Diana was here to take the blame, and Prince William on the other, desperate to avoid a sibling sideshow that will overshadow his entire reign. And hereaposs Harry, slumped on the sofa just as he did after the strip billiards thing, and the Nazi thing, and the cannabis thing, getting it in the earhole and telling them that this time heaposs had enough and wants out. Harryaposs always wanted out. Finally, he has an excuse.  ... I canapost believe youaposve made out this was a surprise. We told you all last year, Harry is saying. You asked me to write down a proposal. I told you it would leak. You insisted, and then it leaked, and now all the Royal reporters are saying youaposre surprised. Truth is, THEYaposRE surprised and youaposre using it against me. Eh  Whataposs that  Canapost hear you, damned thingaposs playing up again, says the Queen, fiddling with a hearing aid she decided would give her some plausible deniability. Weaposd all like out, Harry. We all hate the Press, and we all use it - just as you and your we do, sighs Charles, who has had this argument more than once with every member of his family for  years. Point is, Royals are millionaires who NEED to live like billionaires, or  Richard Branson would seem more royal than us. Weaposre cash-poor, and weaposre not allowed to sell anything. Harry grumbles. Jusapos wanna make money and do good stuff instead of being a lazy arse leeching off the taxpayer infor two daysapos work a week, like the rest of you. How come Iaposm the one in trouble and not the Duke of Dork   BECAUSE YOUaposRE THE ONE ROCKING THE BOAT! Philip is heard bellowing from upstairs. BLOODY I WANT THIS AND THAT AND NOTHINGaposS GOOD ENOUGH. WASNaposT GOOD ENOUGH FOR ME, MY BOY BUT I DAMN WELL PUT UP WITH IT! Told you not to marry an actress, bloody fool thing to do... Harry is outraged. Hang on, Granpa! You reformed the monarchy! TV interviews, a televised coronation, ditching the police guards, driving yourself around London in an environmentally-friendly taxi, the family taking your name - all things they said couldnapost be done! You upturned the Establishment, and now you ARE the Establishment you say I canapost do the same. The Royals all look a bit uncomfortable but the Queen, who has magically heard this bit, says: Weaposve all got things we want to change about the monarchy. But itaposs a constitutional miracle weaposre still here at all. Itaposs a case of softly, softly, catchee monkey. Racist, mutters Harry.  William decides to be big brother. Look, weaposre fine with you leaving. Suits us all, probably. Butyou go now, my children have to put up with more of the attention and we all have to do more work. But Wills,we can make a go of it thereaposll be an exit route for Charlotte and Louis too! bursts out Harry. Theyaposre going to have the same problem as me, as Auntie Margaret - born to be understudies for a role theyaposll never have, and doomed to a le of living off the hospitality of increasingly-rackety friends. Elton John wonapost live forever, you know. The Queen gestures at an aide, who presents Harry with a one-page document from a folder. As you know, one has asked oneaposs advisers for an exit plan. One doesnapost wish to lose you, nor your we, who has managed the astonishing feat of making this family beloved by those parts of the world weaposve literally ridden our horses over. But we canapost have you cocking around with the British constitution. So the plan is, you keep your HRH, strike whatever deals you like, and live where you please. Youaposll still be invited for Christmas and can swan about doing your feminist environmentalism or whatever it is. We want Megxit done quickly and painlessly, so it doesnapost turn into a total saga.  Thereaposs just one catch, the Queen goes on. And itaposs something youaposre probably not expecting. One wants to go with. One wishes to keep oneaposs houses, not Buck House of course, damned thingaposs falling down. But the ponies, the frocks, the right for oneaposs children to pin on medals for things they havenapost done. Colonels will have to colonel their own regiments, Lord Lieutenants can take back control of their own tree-planting ceremonies, Prime Ministers can have sovereignty and see how they bloody like it. One is orf. Iaposm going to call it REXIT. Harry is thunderstruck. But... but... how can you hope to be financially independent  Charles is going to sell Cornwall to pay for the coppers, and weaposll all move in with you and Megsie. The Queen gives a mirthless grin. Givenchy say they want me as brand ambassador, and the government says we can help with trade deals. Meghan will be have to do the chlorinated chicken hard-sell, instead.  But... the constitution... security... the potential for international embarrassment... stutters Harry. All gone, smiles the Queen, waving a hand. If we all go, those problems cease to exist! Itaposs the only way to make it possible, and besides weaposre all stinking jealous of how much money youaposre going to make. Itaposs a case of oneaposs out, all out!And there you have it. The best form of Brexit the UK could enjoy would beevery other EU state were to Leave as well, agreed to follow the same rules, have custom-free trade and frictionless borders. We could call it the EUK. As for Megxit, the only way to remove the political risks of Royals who leave the tent is for the tent to go with them. For both, people can believe they have wrought a great change, while in reality their lives stay comfortably the same. The Queen would never really resign - butthe Good Monday Agreement is good enough, Harry and Meghan will have the right to self-identy as rule-breaking billionaire philanthropists, just so long as they donapost break any rules.

story: NewsTory MP suggests people from certain communities commit disproportionate crimeConservative MP Tom Hunt later suggested he was referring to groups of Eastern European men who gather in Ipswich town centre, saying its just something they tend to doShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsConservative MP Tom Hunt won Ipswich from Labour last month " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA new Tory MP has faced criticism after suggesting people from certain communities commit a disproportionate amount of crime in his seat. Tom Hunt, who won Ipswich from Labour last month, was accused of ill-judged dogwhistling for a column in his local newspaper. Mr Hunt did not say in his column - or a defence of it - which communities he was referring to. But approached by the Mirror today, he suggested he was referring to groups of Eastern European mean in Ipswich town centre. The -year-old said: “One of the things I mentioned in my article was groups of young men in the town centre - often , , acting in a certain way which makes other people in the town feel uncomfortable.  Askedthat was the community he was talking about he replied: “For example,you look at the comments made by Police Superintendent Kerry Cutler from Suffolk, she made the comment that actually in lots of Eastern European communities, particularly the Roma community, lots of young men tend to socialise in large groups in the town centre. “So that’s just - it just seems as though that’s just something they tend to do.” The MPaposs column last Friday in the East Anglian Daily Times said: It is impossible to start thinking about remedies to these issues without also being ready to confront the possibility that a disproportionate number of crimes are committed by iniduals from certain communities. This is something we should be open and honest about. Brushing it under the carpet will not get us closer to solving the issue. Unfortunately, calling things how they are has not been a quality which we have come to expect from many in positions of responsibility on these matters. People who should know better are too quick to spout to politically correct mantras and too slow to call out problems in certain communities, hindering our ability to get to the bottom of the issue and leaving many residents and victims feeling like they donapost have a voice.It went on to attack politically correct mantras and warn against being eternally tolerant of bad behaviour which may be re in other countries. It added: We must acknowledge the many benefits of immigration and respect peopleaposs dferent cultural backgrounds while insisting that those who join our community meet us halfway when it comes to integration. This includes learning English, respecting women and obeying  our laws. A spokesman for the Ipswich and Suffolk Council for Racial Equality told the East Anglian Daily Times the article was at best disappointing and at worst an ill-judged piece of dogwhistling.
